audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male announcer, his voice exhibiting excitement, who says, "65 yards, Raul Allegre, to win it." A sharp sound, possibly a kick, is then heard, followed by the announcer declaring, "And the game is over." Another male voice then enters, speaking in a measured, news-like tone, saying, "Cox attempted to atone for his blocked punt with what would have been an NFL record 64 yard field goal."

The audio clip begins with a sports commentary, remarking that an earlier kick was better than the current one. A second male speaker takes over the commentary, describing a field goal attempt. A crowd cheers loudly as the ball is kicked, transitioning into music of an epic, cinematic style. The music becomes prominent. A final male speaker narrates as the game play continues. At the end of the play, a loud cheering erupts from the audience.

The audio clip features commentary from a male speaker, possibly during a sporting event, describing a play with increasing excitement, highlighted by phrases such as "tied at 23", "looking for the win", and "looking for the record". The speaker has an energetic and enthusiastic tone. A short segment of music follows, but details are unknown.

The audio clip starts with the sounds of a football game, including crowd noise. A male announcer speaks, saying "and Ross on the return" and later mentions "Ross still on his feet." Background sounds of blocks being made can be heard. The announcer continues, describing Ross trying to lateral. The audio briefly cuts out and the background noise of the crowd can be heard. The same male announcer then speaks again, summarizing "comes up short".

The audio clip begins with sounds suggesting a sporting event, as a male announcer speaks about a "64-yard attempt" in an excited tone. Shortly after, there's a sound of a ball being blocked, and the announcer mentions that it is now a "live football."Â  Then, there's another male announcer excitedly describing the kick attempt, noting it "hit the right upright and is no good." Following this, another announcer mentions a potential NFL record "of 65 yards". We can hear the roar of the crowd in the background. He goes on to say someone could run or fumble, and feels badly for the coach. Next, sounds of a cheering crowd permeate the background as another male announcer describes errant kicks, deeming it "no good."

The audio clip begins with a male voice expressing relief, stating "I'm glad in a way because Alex Karras would have broken another helmet." Following this speech, sounds of a sports event become prominent, including crowd noise and a whistle, culminating in an announcer exclaiming it "still has it," referring to a block at the line of scrimmage. The announcer emphasizes an "improbable win" for the Detroit Lions with heightened excitement. Finally, there is some affirmative speech.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing a football play, specifically a "record field goal attempt" and a player named James. His tone is that of a sports announcer, providing play-by-play commentary. This transitions to another male speaker, similarly describing the play but noting that the kick will be "short" within the "thin air of Mile High Stadium."  Ambient crowd noise, consistent with a football game setting, is audible throughout.
The audio clip begins with a background hum accompanied by excited speech. A male voice says "Exciting. Will they listen?".

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing surprise, followed by sounds suggesting a sporting event in a noisy stadium. The sounds include indistinct crowd noise, potentially shouting or cheering. A male commentator's voice emerges to analyze the play, mentioning "gold to chance", assessing the situation, identifying players such as "Patterson", and describing the unfolding action. Throughout the commentary, the background stadium ambiance persists with constant, moderate levels of crowd engagement, culminating as the commentator signals "the final play" with some anticipation.

The clip begins with speech that includes the word "regulation," followed by what sounds like a basketball game announcement, mentioning a player's name and a city, perhaps New Orleans. The speaker's tone is similar to that of an announcer. Sounds of a crowd are present in the background. The announcer then comments on the outcome of a play, stating "Not close." Then announces they will "go to overtime". The crowd sounds persist throughout the clip.

The clip begins with commentary during a sports game, quoting "tied at 20." A male commentator expresses surprise when the kick is no good, stating that the game is over and the Bears won, followed by crowd cheering. The clip shifts to a second sports game with another male commentator saying he missed "in the same area", adding that the Dolphins hold on. Then, a third game with a male commentator stating, "66 yard try", the kick is short and Smooth is still on his feet, followed again by cheering. The clip concludes with another male commentator announcing a "66 yard attempt," with cheers still prominent in the background.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker commentating on a football play, mentioning "caught" and "Rashid Mathis" and indicating someone was "thrown down" and a "flag thrown." Then, another male speaker provides commentary about a field goal attempt and then concluding the kick was "short." This is followed by a crowd noise, seemingly a game ending. The scene transitions with another male speaker stating "and its short," and "Fox goes for the miracle" but "comes up short." The sounds of a sports stadium crowd cheering and shouting fill the background throughout the clip.

The audio clip starts with sounds indicative of a sporting event, possibly football, underscored by background cheering. A male commentator discusses a player's surgery and then describes an on-field play: "3 seconds left in the half, a 68-yard field goal by John Hall." His tone is descriptive and enthusiastic. Another male commentator then describes a "fair catch" and a "free kick," providing details and analysis in an excited tone. The sound of someone shanking a football is then heard. The cheering rises again. A third male commentator states, "68 yards... the kick, short... and the lions get win number 10". The clip then shifts to a new scene with more general crowd cheering. A fourth male speaker comments, "The crowd here at Lambo's loving this... Matt Flynn, the rookie... doing the holding". He then asks another commentator if he thinks the kick will be "close," to which the second speaker replies, "Well, you know, he's going into the wind."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, in an excited tone, referring to "the way the wind blows in your face" before shifting his focus to the game, declaring a chance and exclaiming it fell "just short." The speaker then emphasizes the distance, saying it ended up "about three yards short" but praised the outstanding effort. Then, the speaker details the kick, saying the "free kick from 69 yards out" was "just" before being cut off. Two male speakers then discuss the kick, saying "this would be out of sight," and, comparing to a player last year, claiming it is "risky." The speaker highlights the riskiness, noting the other player's propensity for kicking a line drive.

The clip begins with a sports announcer, speaking with a play-by-play tone, describing a football kickoff, mentioning yard lines and players. The kickoff is executed with a "whooshing" sound. The announcer continues to describe the play with rising enthusiasm. The announcer is briefly interrupted by another male voice with a casual tone, observing the kicker's ability to run. Following this, a distinct "thud" sound is heard, likely the ball being kicked during another kickoff, suggesting a continuation of the sports scenario.

The audio begins with the sounds of a sports game, including ambient crowd noise. An announcer's voice says, "and away," and references returning. The crowd noises become more prominent. Then, we hear a different speaker, possibly a different announcer, mention yardage and taking the ball on the ground. A third person says, "unimaginable". This is followed by another person talking about "three-step start" for a "little NFL history".

The audio begins with male speech discussing a football player named Lechler and describing his actions on the field as "half loafing" and trying to seduce the defense. The speaker's tone is analytical and descriptive. This transitions to music with a hip-hop style and a somewhat melancholic mood, featuring string instruments as a key element.
